Comment: e4. A standard choice for me which I tend to do better with thn d4.
Black opts for the Sicilian. A solid choice against e4 which statistically has the best results for wins and draws.
Standard developing move which controls d4 and d5.

This Queen side pawn push starts an early attack for white while freeing up the b7 square for the light square bishop.

Developing the dark square bishop and protecting the knight on d4. If black continues to push his b pawn then I anticipated Nd5. The alternative move I considered was f3, keeping blacks Knight off of g4.
As anticipated...
Nd4 attacking the Queen and anticipating and exchange of Knights.

Rather than exchange bishops on the d7 square I wanted to maintain development and move toward castling but at this stage not sure which side. I was a bit concerned about the Queenside pawns so will probably castle king side.

I made this move some time after my previous move and forgot about the knight being attacked on d4. A mistake I often make in correspondence chess. Fingers crossed he misses it.
Phew. Developing the knight and attacking my knight I decide to trade off.

Trading knights. At this point in the game the material is even. Advantages for white are that I have castled and development is proceeding. However I have a couple of unprotected pawns. Black has not yet castled but has advances and opportunities on the Queenside.
